newsitem.title: BELGIUM: Ministers raise agrimoney compensation limit to 11.5 pct.
newsitem.headline: Ministers raise agrimoney compensation limit to 11.5 pct.

text.p: Farm ministers agreed on Wednesday to raise the limit on compensation to farmers for income loss due to a revaluation of the so-called green rate to 11.5 percent, from a proposed 7.0 percent, EU officials and diplomats said.
Three countries, Britain, Ireland and Italy, had been blocking a European Commission proposal to limit the amount of compensation that farmers could receive.

The three countries currencies have recently undergone a series of revaluations and the Commission estimated that compensation under existing rules would have cost a prohibitive 1.8 billion ecus in 1998 and following years.
The British green rate, which is used to convert ecu-based subsidies into pounds, was facing a revaluation of just over 11 percent on March 29.
The 11.5 percent limit would initially apply only to Britain but would be extended to all other member states after this month's expected green rate revaluation.
The three countries had said that the measure would be discriminatory because it did not apply to Germany, the Netherlands and six other countries which revalued in the past.

In a move to satisfy Italy, the reference period for calculating compensation after a major revaluation was halved to six months and a minimum 150 ecus per farmer aid level abolished and replaced by a more flexible yardstick -- 0.5 percent of the revaluation.
The minimum level originally proposed would have excluded most Italian farmers.
